para.text: The installation process will have created an image file for you and it is this that you must open to start Dolphin. Depending on whether you installed Dolphin from the binary installer or from the GitHub sources, you may find the default image file in one of two places. In the case of the binary installer, you'll find a
directory. For the GitHub sources you'll find the same file in the directory where you cloned or forked the Dolphin repository.

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:9px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

para.text: The image files should have an "objects inside" icon associated with them, which should make it easy to locate them within your working folder.
In order to start Dolphin with a particular image file it is simply necessary to double click the
file. Alternatively, you may drag the image and drop it over the
Obviously, if you wish, you can also create a shortcut icon to your image file on the desktop.
After starting Dolphin, you will initially see the
window, which we will discuss in the next section.
